description.narrative: Improving sustainability of the Protected Area system in desert ecosystems through promotion of biodiversity-compatible livelihoods in and around Protected Areas
The project objective is to enhance the sustainability of protected areas in globally important desert and semi-desert ecosystems
capital of a political entity
Environment - policy, planning and administration

1. Improved bio-geographic coverage of PA system: by 2020 an additional 5.3 million ha of the least represented desert and semi-desert ecosystems added to the PA estate. 2. Integrated land-use planning under implementation at 9 million ha of desert landscapes, ensuring preservation of ecosystem functions. 3. Demonstration of effective mechanisms and tools for engagement of local communities and other non-PA actors in PA management.

comment.narrative: 1. The current PA system falls short in terms of its bio-geographic representation, with desert ecosystems being currently under-represented. 2. PA design and expansion decisions are not considering the broader, landscape-level processes. 3. Collaborative management in PA governance in Kazakhstan remains a gap.

1. Work on the expansion of the SPNA system in the desert and semi-desert ecosystems of Kazakhstan. 2. Enhancing the efficiency of management and strengthening the staff capacity of the pilot SPNA s. 3. Creating conditions for the habitation and migration of large hoofed mammals (kulan, gazelle) at the territory of the Altyn Emel National Park. 4. Development of a training program for middle age school children in the conservation of desert ecosystems. 5. Preparation of the Concept of sustainable land management for the Aral-Syrdarya and Ile-Balkashs project areas. 6. Demonstration of the 10 sustainable practices to reduce land degradation, management of riparian woodland and saxaul forests and wetlands, development of ecotourism in the 3 project areas. 7. Determination of the boundaries of the ecological corridor at the Ile-Balkashs project area. 8. Expansion of the Information biodiversity monitoring system and establishment of a system of information on the condition of desert and semi-desert ecosystems. 9. Establishment of the Public Council under the Ustyurtskiy Reserve and enhancing the capacity of the existing Public Councils. 10. Determination of the economic value of ecosystem services and introduction of pilot PES schemes in the project areas. 11. Economic evaluation and development of compensatory mechanisms for the loss of biodiversity in the Kansu area near the Ustyurtskiy Reserve. 12. Monitoring and evaluation of the sustainability of microcredit projects implemented under the Eco-Damu Microcredit Programme.

description.narrative: To enhance the sustainability of protected areas in globally important desert and semidesert ecosystems by expanding their geographic coverage promoting a landscape approach and supporting biodiversitycompatible livelihoods in and around PAs
Coverage of underrepresented Mountainvalley subtype desert in the PA System of Kazakhstan

comment.narrative: 99704 ha 33 of ecological zone

By 2015 coverage of Mountainvalley subtype desert in PA system increases by 1602504 ha 534 of the ecological zone This increase comes from the following
Establishment of 1 new PA IleBalkhash State Nature Reserve covering 442296 ha
Expansion of 1 existing PA Altyn Yemel State National Nature Park by 460208 ha
Establishment of a wildlife corridor between Altyn Yemel and IleBalkhash PAs of 700000 ha
By 2020 coverage of Mountainvalley subtype desert in PA system increases by approximately 30000 ha 1 of the ecological zone This increase comes from the following
Establishment of 1 new PA Arganaty covering approximately 30000 ha

99704 ha 33 of ecological zone as in the baseline
The following works have been initiatedcompleted by the project to ensure the achievement of the EoP target
works were performed on land plots of 152000 ha total to establish the IleBalkhash nature reservat The feasibility study TEO was approved by the authorized body report on the positive state ecological appraisal was obtained
Draft Decree of RK Government on expansion of the Altyn Yemel State National Nature Parks area at 146500 ha is being approved by concerned authorities
field studies on habitation of rare ungulate species of animals of Altyn Yemel and IleBalkhash PAs were conducted Habitation and animal migration maps were drawn for three routes with total length of 664 km The results of scientific works will be used for establishment of the proposed ecological corridor
the work on the ENO development for PA establishment in Arganaty plot is being performed The current status of mountainvalley desert ecosystems of the IleBalkhash project area was assessed
Data reported
1Technical economic background report or TEO to establish the IleBalkhash nature reservat
2 Draft Decree of RK Government on expansion of the Altyn Yemel National Park
3 Assessment of wildlife condition and migratory routes

description.narrative: Coverage of underrepresented Southern desert in the PA System of Kazakhstan

comment.narrative: 1591800 ha 53 of ecological zone

By 2015 coverage of Southern desert in PA system increases by 2682032 ha 89 of the ecological zone This increase comes from the following
Establishment of 1 new PA Mangistau State Reserved Zone covering 2676262 ha
Expansion of 1 existing PA Barsakelmes State Nature Reserve by 5770 ha
By 2020 coverage of Southern desert in PA system increases by approximately 970000 ha 32 of the ecological zone This increase comes from
Expansion of 1 existing PA Ustyurt State Nature Reserve by approximately 220000 ha
Establishment of a wildlife corridor between Barsakelmes and Ustyurt PAs of approximately 750000 ha

1591800 ha 53 of ecological zone as in the baseline
The following activities have been initiatedcompleted by the project to ensure the achievement of the EoP target
Plan of land boundaries allotment for establishment of Mangistau protected area of total area 2600000 ha is being approved by local government akimat of Mangistau Oblast
Works on approval of land use design and feasibility study TEO to expand Barsakelmes reserves area at local government akimat level of Kyzylorda Oblast were performed
dialogue platform was created to openly discuss issues related to adding 23000 ha of the Syrdaria river delta to the Barsakelmes reserve
scientific background report ENO for expansion of the Ustyurt reserves area to 704000 ha 23 of ecological zone was developed ENO was approved by the authorized body report on the positive state ecological appraisal was obtained The feasibility study TEO to expand the reserves area is being developed
field studies on habitation of rare ungulate species of animals between Barsakelmes and Ustyurt PAs were conducted Habitation and animal migration maps were drawn for three routes with total length of 841 km The results of scientific works will be used to establish the proposed ecological corridor

For the reporting period the state of saxaul and tugai forests was assessed ways of conservation and restoration of such forests were identified
To restore saxaul forests in the AralSyrdaria region a project on establishment of forest nursery for saxaul and other hardyshrub species is being implemented As a result for the reporting period 1500 ha of saxaul were planted in the Aral pilot area

comment.narrative: Kazakhstan has completed its TNC/6NC and first BR and prepared an inventory report. Many previously submitted national communications still have information and data gaps

Target of 2016 is: 1. Recruitment of 4 national experts (TeamLeaders) for the NC development 3. Determination and hiring of experts (thematic experts) that will be involved in prepartion of 7th national communication 4. Capacity building activities for the experts and institutions and awaraness raising among the country 5. Development of first draft version of NC

Line experts (thematic experts) was identified and hired and was involved in prepartion of 7th national communication 4. Capacity building activities for the experts and institutions and awaraness raising among the country was done 5. First draft version of several NC chapters was developed

Target of 2017 is: 1. Development of draft and final versions of NC 2. Determination and hiring of experts (thematic experts) that will be involved in prepartion of 7th national communication 3. Agreemnet of the NC with line ministries and experts 4. Upload NC to the UNFCCC website

1. Draft version of NC was developed and agreed with experts and Ministries 2. Final versions of NC was developed and presented to the public 2. Experts was involved in prepartion of 7th national communication and participated in the presentation 4. NC uploaded to the UNFCCC website

Target of 2018 is: 1. Promoting of findings of NC 2. Support of Natiional GHG traiding system 3. Publications of new Climate Change related data 3. Supporting of the longterm climate predictions (assist to the team via digitalizing methods)

description.narrative: The IRRF is UNDP’s results framework to monitor and report on its achievements against the Strategic Plan 2014-2017. UNDP publishes country level IRRF results that UNDP’s projects contributed to
total number of new full-time equivalent jobs created
number of additional people benefitting from UNDP's livelihoods interventions
- Central and local actors acquire tools and methodologies for IWRM (Integrated Water Resource Management) and fostering trans-boundary dialogue.
capital of a political entity
policy, planning and administration
Contribute to the long-term environmental sustainability and inclusive economic development of Kazakhstan through supporting the country's transition to a Green Economy model.

comment.narrative: In the follow-up to the Rio+20 process on sustainable development, Kazakhstan took a landmark decision to transition towards a sustainable Green Economy Concept, aimed at implementing a completely new development paradigm with particular focus on the water sector.

Interim report of grant programme implementation, contracts for 4 pilot projects are signed, starting of pilot projects implementation, to prepare report on economic instruments in two sectors of Kazakhstan, to prepare a plan for Balkhash Alakol bassin saving, workshop and report on green indicators, review on dams in Kazakhstan

Under the pilot activities, on the territory of greenhouse facility, Training Center for Green Technologies has been established to train farmers, students, master's degree students, entrepreneurs and others. The trainees will be provided with practical skills required for agrarian sector, and will also study elements of the most promising energy and resource saving technologies that will help improve methods and ways of growing vegetables in a protected soil, and effectively use heat and energy, natural resources, and ways of provision of fresh vegetables to population round the year. Due to the grant program, 14 NGOs were supported to implement projects related to green economy. Overall, water consumption for irrigation at the pilot sites have been reduced 40%. Energy efficiency rose up to 20%, due to technologies harvesting of farmers increased up to 20%, water supply improved for 700 residents; 8 schools have access to clean water and 6 social buildings have access to hot water. 7 green business models have been developed and supported within the project through contest among youth, such as Water in AUL and Startup Bolashak. Green economy elements were integrated into the Balkhash-Alakol Basin Saving and Management Plan. This will enable to improve water quality and water disposal management of the Basin.

The target for the joint EU/UNDP/UNECE project is to demonstrate social, environmental and economic viability of the green technologies for water sector. The target will be achieved thought implementation of pilot projects in Astana city, Almaty, Aktobe and Kyzyl Orda regions. Moreover, project is setting up the targets such as: increasing visibility and awareness of the green technologies and build the capacity of the stakeholders in this area. These targets will be implemented in partnership with leading universities and civil society organizations of Kazakhstan.

The intended synergies between the key pillars of the project, i.e. improved governance of natural resources, increased efficiency in water management, the introduction of innovative technologies and economic considerations are increasingly becoming apparent. Legal approaches, economic considerations, innovative technologies, and novel business models come together in the series of pilot projects, which have been designed and partly constructed during this reporting period. Namely, Aktobe pilot project was totally completed and deliverables transferred to the Oblast Akimat. Kyzyl-Orda, Astana and Almaty projects are in an active implementation stage. The grant program focusing on civils society has been completed in August 2017 and provides examples of the synergies to be expected in the implementation of the three major pilot projects currently being realized. The target was implemented in strong partnership with leading universities, IFIs, state bodies and civil society organizations of Kazakhstan.

4 pilot projects in KZO, Almaty region, Astana and Aktobe are finalized. The final feasibility study on Kargaly reservoir are prepared, the positive government expertise is received. The feasibility study provided to the relevant government bodies for the further implementation. The Conference is conducted for presentation of the pilot projects results and distribution of the received impacts. The HACT modality initiative with CAREC on Sharing knowledge and expertise in modern methods of water management is implemented. Training modules on pilot projects are created, trainings are conducted for the participants from Central Asia. Final reports are prepared and endorsed by national partner and donor

policy, planning and administration

1. Pastures and crop land capacity assessed and incorporated as active components in Integrated Land Use Plans, Improved 20 000 of abandoned lands through introduction of at least three new advanced practices on pasture logging/watering Decrease grazing rate of moderately degraded pastures by 40%; 2. At least two policy and legal documents regulating system of agricultural subsidies in Kazakhstan 3. promotes small-scale holders leading to soil and vegetation quality improvements. 4. Pastures and crop land capacities assessed and incorporated as active components in Integrated Land Use Plans, 5. At least two state programs reorient funding from traditional to ‘green’ agriculture.

comment.narrative: 1. Land use planning does not account for ecosystem values, leading to ecosystem degradation 2. Absence of advanced practices on pasture logging/watering; 3. Inadequate policy and legal framework to support a transformation to SLM 4. Traditional subsidies in agriculture prioritize productivity and take no heed of ecosystem carrying capacity 5. Limited and inefficient investments in pasture and maintenance of productive landscapes

At least 2 ILUP are developed One methodology is developed to promote pasture land inventories. At least 5 new advanced agro technologies are introduced on productive agro landscapes. One pasture crops seed farming enterprise is established. At least 3 new effective agro effective agro incentive modules and mechanism to promote productive land scape management are introduced. At least one inter-ministerial task force group to promote the development of ILUP is established and functional. At least one policy and legal document harmonized to promote the issues of effective productive landscape management.

3 ILUPs hase been developed in Kyzylorda and Akmola regions 3 methodologies has been developed to promote pasture land inventories 5 new advanced agro technologies has been introduced on productive agro landscapes 1 pasture crops seed farming enterprise has been established 3 new effective agro effective agro incentive modules and mechanism to promote productive land scape management have been introduced 1 inter-ministerial task force group to promote the development of ILUP has been established and functional 1 policy and legal document harmonized to promote the issues of effective productive landscape management

At least 2 comprehensive recomendation is elaborated to update ILUPs in targated regions. 7 new advanced agro technologies are introduced on productive agro landscapes. 4 pasture crops seed farming enterprise is established. At least 3 new effective agro incentive modules and mechanism to promote productive land scape management are introduced. At least one inter-ministerial task force group to promote the development of ILUP is established and functional. At least one policy and legal document harmonized to promote the issues of effective productive landscape management.

2 comprehensive reccomendations have been elaborated to update ILUPs in targated regions. 12 new advanced agro technologies have been introduced on productive agro landscapes. 4 pasture crops seed farming enterprise have been established in Kostanay, East-Kazakhstan, Kyzylorda and Almaty oblasts 3 new effective agro incentive modules and mechanism to promote productive land scape management have been introduced. 1 inter-ministerial task force group to promote the development of ILUP has been established and functional. 5 policy and legal document harmonized to promote the issues of effective productive landscape management.

description.narrative: Promoting Kazakhstan’s Official Development Assistance Cooperation with Afghanistan
Promoting Kazakhstan’s Official Development Assistance Cooperation with Afghanistan
capital of a political entity

comment.narrative: Role of women professionals in healthcare and civil service is low. Nascent capacity of the Kazakhstan’s ODA staff.
Project manager and assistant are hired. Provided with necessary equipment. Conducting project related research, networking, etc.

1) To empower Afghan officials with professional knowledge in the area of civil service and promote the role of women. 2) To promote the role of Afghan women and empower them with professional knowledge in the area of healthcare. 3) Kaz ODA/MFA staff is capacitated to plan, implement, and monitor the ODA projects through “learning-by-doing” approach 4) The project is managed effectively with participation of the KAZ ODA/MFA personnel temporarily involved

- At least 20 civil servants from Afghanistan (not less than 80% female and 60% from rural area) are trained during a weeklong capacity building seminar in Astana. - Developed training curriculum and selected at least 30 healthcare workers (preferably rural and urban women nurses and family doctors) for a weeklong capacity building seminar in Astana. - At least 5 Kaz ODA/MFA personnel are taught and apply effective policies and practices in the field of ODA.

1) To develop capacity of Afghan Public Health Workers in the field of maternal and child healthcare by utilizing the experience of Kazakhstan and identifying/promoting cheap and easy to maintain healthcare equipment. 2) To inform the wider audience about Kazakh ODA efforts and achievements. 3) To build capacity of KazODA/MFA personnel in the ODA project management cycle.

- At least 30 Afghan Public Health Workers (not less than 80% female and 60% from rural area) are trained during a two weeklong capacity building seminar in Astana. - KazODA/MFA personnel learned about project management and principles of ODA at half a day long workshop. - Wider audience is aware about Kazakh ODA activities via online publications, including on the UNDP and MFA websites.

description.narrative: Assistance in promoting gender equality and practical implementation of the UN Committee’s comments to Kazakhstan on implementation of the CEDAW in compliance with international commitments.
The project will assist the National Commission in advancing women throughout the country.
capital of a political entity
Other General Services - support to civil society

comment.narrative: Capacity building events resulted in a comprehensive and accountable implementation of the Concept and the consolidation of innovative methods of family and gender policies realization Monitoring of the implementation of the concluding observations of the UN Committee on the Elimination of Discrimination against Women on the combined the 3rd and 4th periodic reports of Kazakhstan An independent peer review was provided on on the implementation of the Convention. Methodological recommendations on the implementation of the Family and Gender Policy Concept in the Republic of Kazakhstan 2017-2030

Monitoring of the implementation of the concluding observations of the UN Committee on the Elimination of Discrimination against Women on the combined the 3rd and 4th periodic reports of Kazakhstan was launched. An independent peer review was provided on this issue, as well as objective data on the implementation of the Convention. Methodological recommendations on the implementation of the Family and Gender Policy Concept in the Republic of Kazakhstan 2017-2030 for central and local executive authorities have been developed. For the first time in the country, the "Gender Audit" was conducted using the example of the Nazarbayev University curriculum: a pilot project on gender audit in Kazakhstan organizations "and a universal methodology for gender audit in any organization (private and public) was developed. Support was provided in the development of the concept of the draft Law of the Republic of Kazakhstan "On Amendments and Additions to Certain Legislative Acts of the Republic of Kazakhstan on Matters of Family and Gender Policy".

title.narrative: Energy Efficient Standards, Certification, and Labelling

description.narrative: The objective of the project is to transform Kazakhstan’s markets to energy efficient appliances and equipment, thereby reducing electricity consumption and GHG emissions

title.narrative: Ref.2018-0011_International Expert on Energy Efficiency in Production and Operation of Transformers in Kazakhstan

description.narrative: The IRRF is UNDP’s results framework to monitor and report on its achievements against the Strategic Plan 2014-2017. UNDP publishes country level IRRF results that UNDP’s projects contributed to
Number of new development partnerships with funding for improved energy efficiency and/or sustainable energy solutions targeting underserved communities/groups and women

The project will pursue regulations and labelling for the three categories of appliances and equipment with the highest electricity consumption and impact – refrigerators, industrial motors, and distribution transformers.
capital of a political entity
Energy - power generation

1. Reduction in electricity consumption by refrigerators, distribution transformers, and electric motors
2. Reduction in GHG emissions from electricity consumption by refrigerators, distribution transformers, and electric motors

comment.narrative:
1. 40 TWh of electricity per year consumed by refrigerators, motors, and distribution transformers (transformer losses), projected to grow to 87 TWh per year by 2030 under business as usual
2. 37 million tonnes of CO2 emissions per year from electricity consumption by refrigerators, motors, and distribution transformers, projected to grow to 80 million tonnes of CO2 emissions per year by 2030 under business as usual

1. Preparing review on adoption of the national MEPS for refrigerators, distribution transformers, and industrial motors in Kazakhstan; 2. Forming of a contact working group for discussion of energy efficiency standards. 3. Data collection (average loss calculation) of energy efficiency and analysis of energy consumption of refrigerators, distribution transformers, and electric motors to prepare the baseline 4. Analysis of the current situation and development of recommendations regarding monitoring and control of following the energy efficiency standards of refrigerators, distribution transformers and industrial motors 5. Based on analysis there shall be defined the list of the needed equipment to perform tests and certification of electric appliances and equipment 6. Preparation of technical documents and holding of a tender for sociological research regarding consumers awareness on advantages of energy efficient equipment and appliances. 7. Preparation of technical documentation a tender for analysis of financial mechanisms, discounts and coupons for energy efficient technologies. 8. Preparation of technical documents a tender for market research on its current quantities, trends of sale and use of refrigerators, freezers, and other domestic appliances in regards of energy efficiency.

title.narrative: Improvement of the National Human Rights Protection

description.narrative: Improvement of the National Human Rights Protection Mechanisms and Facilitation of Effective Implementation of the International Commitments of the Republic of Kazakhstan: Phase II
Improvement of the National Human Rights Protection Mechanisms and Facilitation of Effective Implementation of the International Commitments of the Republic of Kazakhstan
capital of a political entity
Environment - policy, planning and administration

National system for assessing the performance of the State's international obligations in the sphere of protection of human rights, based on common global indicators is introduced Coordination bodies exist for monitoring implementation of the recommendations of the UN treaty bodies in the sphere of human rights protection.

comment.narrative: Lacks of mechanisms for coordination and evaluation of the State's obligations under international conventions ratified by Kazakhstan in human rights protection

Assist in the formation of a holistic approach to reform policy in the field of human rights and implementation of international obligations of the Republic of Kazakhstan. The effective implementation of policies in the field of human rights and the strengthening of institutions at all levels of execution

Recommendations have been provided to improve legislation to the state of compliance with the norms of international human right treaties that Kazakhstan has ratified. Participation in expert and government meetings with discussion of policy and strategy of implementation of UPR and other recommendations on human rights. Training programs and training materials have been developed to increase knowledge and potential of law enforcement bodies on the issues of effective investigation of tortures, including specific program for medical experts

Assist in the formation of a holistic approach to reform policy in the field of human rights and implementation of international obligations of the Republic of Kazakhstan. The effective implementation of policies in the field of human rights and the strengthening of institutions at all levels of execution

Analysis of implementation of 2nd UPR recommendations and implementation of ICCPR has been conducted and passed to the government agencies. National experts reviewed OHCHR developed human right indicators and elaborated Meta-data for Kazakhstan to further validate with government bodies and initiate collection of data on human rights implementation. Project supported the government and civil society organized meetings on promotion of human rights mechanisms and legislative changes in Kazakhstan, including support with international expertise for UPR conference and webinar discussion of gender based violence issues. Training workshops for special prosecutors, forensic experts, and police staff on Istanbul Protocol based effective investigation of torture and on GBV case management enhanced their knowledge on international standards. Trainings on draft law revision increased potential of public council members in greater participation in decision making process. National experts developed training programs for press services of government agencies on international human rights commitments of Kazakhstan to enhance their knowledge on human right treaties and skills to work with mass media on the issues of human rights implementation. The training program was developed for law enforcement bodies on management of peaceful assemblies to support next year training for police staff.

description.narrative: Provision of technical assistance.Training and infrastructure needs assessment of the Judicial Academy of the Republic of Kazakhstan
Provision of technical assistance.Training and infrastructure needs assessment of the Judicial Academy of the Republic of Kazakhstan
capital of a political entity
Anti corruption

1. The recommendations of the project to improve the initial training of candidates for judges. 2. The recommendations of the project to improve the training of trainers (ToT) system for professors and lecturers of the Academy. 3. The recommendations of the project to set up system of mandatory training for judges and court clerks to be delivered at the Academy both online and offline. 4. Provision of recommendations on modernization of tasks and approaches to research at the Scientific Research Center of the Academy. 5. Providing advice on development of conceptual design for the new building of the Academy and modern ICT to be used for training purposes. 6. Development of mid-term Strategy for Development of the Academy and New Financial Model to ensure long-term sustainability of the Academy’s activities.

comment.narrative: 1. Low level of the Academy’s graduates becoming judges. 2. Low level of judges providing training at the Academy. 3. Low level of judges and court clerks going through the on-job training. 4. Low level of scientific research at the Academy. 5. Insufficient physical infrastructure (lack of space for training purposes) and ICT. 6. Insufficient funding of the key areas of Academy’s activities.

1) Identify the training and academic needs of the Academy and submit the interim assessment to the Supreme Court as the designated beneficiary. 2) Assess physical and ICT infrastructure of the Academy and submit the interim assessment to the to the Supreme Court as the designated beneficiary.

1) Training needs of the Academy are identified. All relevant information included in the Inception report which was accepted by the designated beneficiary in September 2017. Best global practices to assess medium and to long-term training needs of the judiciary reviewed, gaps in training needs were identified. All relevant information included in the Interim report which was submitted to the designated beneficiary in December 2017. 2) Current physical and ICT infrastructure was analyzed and assessed by project experts in October – November 2017. Recommendations on spatial requirements, which could represent the best solution for permanent premises for a modern 21st century Academy of Justice are provided. All relevant information included in the Interim report which was submitted to the designated beneficiary in December 2017.

1) Prepare a draft Strategy for Development of the Judicial Academy, Implementation Mechanisms and Training and Infrastructure Financing Action Plan and submit to the Supreme Court as the designated beneficiary.

1) Draft Strategy for Development of the Judicial Academy, Implementation Mechanisms and Training and Infrastructure Financing Action Plan were prepared in cooperation with the Supreme Court and Judicial Academy. The proposed Strategy is built on the best practices of judicial training in the OECD countries and it promotes (i) replacement of the exisiting Mastar's in Law programme with the initial training programme for the future candidates; (ii) introduction of the mandatory continious training for judges, court clerks, chairmen of courts (at least 40 hours per annum); (iii) modernisation of the infrastructure and ICT to the level of the best judicial training schools in the OECD member states.

description.narrative: Assessment to enable the country to determine the national requirements and needs for ratification of the Minamata Convention

capital of a political entity

National Mercury Inventory for Kazakhstan completed

comment.narrative: The initial mercury assessment (inventory) was conducted. No previous Minamata assessment on mercury prepared at national level.
The assessment of the results of the first stage of inventarization in Kazakhstan was held within the chemical mattars and waste management Project. Public and key stakeholder consultations held.

The report was discussed with interested sides, and was submitted in Inception workshop. For the realization purposes in the part of creation mechanism of the project it was conducted work meeting with the Governmental bodies. With the purpose of capacity building it was conducted a seminar with industrial eterprices of energy, mining and smelting and oil sector.

title.narrative: Sixth Operational Phase of the GEF Small Grants Programm

description.narrative: Resilient rural and peri-urban landscapes of steppe and desert ecosystems for sustainable development and global environmental protection
Resilient rural and peri-urban landscapes of steppe and desert ecosystems for sustainable development and global environmental protection
capital of a political entity
Social Protection, Land Housing and Community Amenities - disaster prevention and preparedness

70,000 hectares is the area under resilient landscape management whose biodiversity, agro-ecosystems, and sustainable livelihoods are protected At least fifty organizations strengthened in technical, organizational and financial capacities (at least 30% led by women) avg direct beneficiaries per project 50, total 2,500 persons At least 8 energy efficient technologies piloted successfully in 7 pilot sites 795,6 tones of CO2 emissions are avoided At least 7 baseline landscape assessments done At least 7 functioning platforms (one per oblast), which include landscape policy considerations in their work-planning established At least 7 landscape strategies, one for targeted site is developed and implemented to achieve greater social and ecological resilience At least 50 community-based projects, implemented by CBOs and NGOs in partnership with others in the targeted landscapes, as outputs to achieve landscape level outcomes 40% of beneficiaries (disaggregated by gender) increased incomes as a result of sustainable and/or alternative practices At least five new technologies, practices or systems are replicated and up-scaled beyond the landscapes through the use of strategic projects 20-25 lessons learned documents developed; 7 case studies developed (1 per landscape) 100% of publications are gender-sensitive

comment.narrative:
Structural and functional degradation of desert and steppe ecosystems is occurring across Kazakhstan with the loss of important biodiversity and ecosystem services.
Wind and water erosion primarily due to unsustainable farming practices (crop and rice production) and extensive resource use (grazing, wood and grass harvesting) affect over 67 % of rain-fed areas of steppe and desert ecosystems, resulting in the loss of organic matter in topsoil (20% in the past 30 years) and reduction of crop yields by 20-30%.
The increasing annual harvest of riparian trees and reeds by local communities, local hunters, fishermen and farmers for use as fuel and for sale as well as for creating areas for fishing, grazing and harvesting has led to a dramatic reduction of the area and diversity of wooded zones.
Overgrazing is the leading cause of degradation of Kazakhstan’s rangelands, making this important agroecosystem susceptible to droughts, inadequate natural regeneration, widespread aerial transportation of sand and salt (affecting some 30 million ha) and formation of salinized or “solonchak” lands (more than 93 million ha). Pasturelands in Kazakhstan are affected by uneven use. Over 125 million ha of pastures lack watering points, thus restricting their utilization. On the other hand, some pastures are being over used - about 27.1 million ha of pastures that are located around settlements are classified as highly degraded due to unsustainable use.
Unsustainable hunting and fishing is on the rise.
Household and hazardous waste accumulation is increasing in rural and peri-urban areas.
Being a semiarid to arid country with a temperate climate, Kazakhstan faces significant desiccation in the face of climate change, and significant exacerbation of non-climate pressures.
The essential problem to be addressed by this project is that the necessary collective action in Kazakhstan for adaptive management of resources and ecosystem processes for sustainable development and global

1) Inception workshop arrangement with participation of main partners to discuss the project approach, Project Logframe, AWP for 2017-2018. 2) NSC approval of the Project, Logframe&AWP for 2017-2018. Preparation of the Inception report taking into account all the comments and changes. 3) Preparation for the baseline assessment in focal landscapes (7 oblasts)

1) The Inception workshop (both Internal & External session) was held on 30-31 October 2017 in Astana with participation of the main SGP partners from amongst CSOs, Local communities representatives, UNDP CO, UCP UNDP/GEF Global Manager, government officials, farmers, women association representatives, NSC members, experts on BD, CC, LD&gender experts. The Project Logframes& AWP were discussed, added and approved. 2) SGP NSC members approved the Project, AWP for 2017-2018 and Logframes on 23 November 2017. The inception report is prepared and shared with GEF UNDP UCP Manager and UNDP CO for comments. 3) Competition among NGOs for the baseline assessment to be arranged in focal landscapes in 2018 was held on 23 November. The NSC reviewed all the submitted applications, and approved the grant of $50,000 for Decenta PF. The MOA signed, the Baseline assessment workplan, budget, ToRs for experts approved.

title.narrative: Integrated Dryland and Drought Management in South Kazak

description.narrative: Livelihood strategies and resilience of vulnerable farmers and pastoral communities in the selected pilot sites improved and sustained to cope with drought
This project is also establishing the use of drought early warning systems to boost resilience in the agricultural sector which may serve for the interest of the whole country

Number of droguth reports prpoduced Number of documented best practices on drought mitigation and management Number of training modules and farmers with improved knowledge. Number of drought management centers established. Number of farmers with improved knowledge and expereince Number of demonstration plots established Number of farmers with access to advanced drought management practices

comment.narrative: Absence of comprehensive drought situational analyses Absence of documented locally available and international best practices on drought management Absence of effective drought management training modules Absence of drought information center acessible to the farming business planning. Few farmers posses advanced knowledge on drought mitigation and management No demonstration plots with advabced droguth mitigation and adaptation agrotechnologies to showcase Few farmers have access to advanced drought management agro technology

At least 12 best practices are documented At least 2 new training modules developed 1 drought mitigation geoportal established At least 200 farmers are benefitied from using drought geoportal Established 6 demonstration plot on restoration of abandoned pasture lands through cultivation of pasture plants as well as 1 nurseries. Establioshed 1 agroforestry demonstration plots to showcase the advanced crop and plot diversification technology with drought tolerant crops\trees and develop eroded slope lands and ensure income generation from the abandoned lands.

12 best practices are documented 1 new training module developed 70 farmers are benefitied from using drought geoportal Established 4 demonstration plot on restoration of abandoned pasture lands through cultivation of pasture plants as well as 1 nurseries. description.narrative: Support to capacity development of the National Scientific Center of Phthisiopulmonology of the Ministry of Health of the Republic of Kazakhstan in implementation of grants of the Global Fund to fight AIDS, Tuberculosis and Malaria
capital of a political entity
Anti corruption
All planned shipments in line with approved Procurement Plan are organized; all distributions and deliveries of ordered health products to each of 20 TB end-users are finished.

comment.narrative: National TB facilities are lack of essential TB products to continue qualitative provision of their services to population RK. National TB partner requires capacity building support in the field of procurement of goods and services.

1) To effect local procurement of Hain and Bactec reagents for 2017 and deliver them to local TB laboratories. 2) To make international procurement of ARV pharmaceuticals for 2018-2019 and deliver procured goods to local TB laboratories. 3) Make a local or international order of Hain and Bactec reagents for 2018-2019. 4) Hire local logistics company to provide logistics and warehousing services while international procurement of goods and their in-country distribution.

1) Hain reagents are delivered and distributed among TB end-users; Bactec reagents will be supplied in early 2018 upon prior agreement with TB PR. 2) ARV pharmaceuticals order is in process, the goods are planned to be supplied in mid 2018. 3) Basing upon performance of the local Hain and Bactec suppliers, local or international procurement will be organized in early 2018 4) The local company hired in summer 2017 to perform logistics and warehousing as per HIV Project will continue services provision to TB Project as well.

1) To effect local procurement of Hain reagents for 2018 and deliver them to local TB laboratories. 2) To issue a PO for international procurement of ARV pharmaceuticals for 2018-2019. Deliver health products required for 2018 and distribute among local TB laboratories. 3) Make international order of Bactec reagents for 2018-2019. Effect delivery of goods required for 2018 and distribute among local TB laboratories.
